Did you mouse over the bcc and cc items? It will show you the keyboard hints for ctrl+shift+c and ctrl+shift+b

content:
@Wayne WOW, thank you. The small note in Account settings -> Copies and Folders section was too small to notice it! I'll explain here, because it is not very clear:

In Account settings -> Copies and Folders section there are 2 check marks to activate 2 fields:

  • CC = send always to CC to the following emails
  • BCC =send always to CC to the following emails

... and a very small note that says leave fields blank show the CC and BCC blocks when composing an email.

So you have to put the checks on the fields, but leave the field blank!!!

@david David, the standard behavior is composer without CC and BCC fields shown.

content:
Sure is a real problem. It is called Microsoft.

No I am not just Microsoft bashing, but because they are a big player they do not feel constrained to actually offer a product that works with anything but other Microsoft products. Recently they started implementing oauth authentication. But in typical Microsoft fashion they called it "modern Authentication" and it only "sort of" the open oauth protocol.

The result is confusing discussions like https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1528136 and https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1685414 and folk trying to help by making updates automatic. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1798875

That works while folk have not blocked the necessary cookies, or actually complete the authentication flow. Lots just closed the web page and sought support because there was an annoying popup blocking them from getting mail.

I really do not have the answers, just a load of confusion.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: If you use certain providers and IMAP then they remove the BCC information from the sent folder. Google being on of those providers. There is nothing Thunderbird can do if the provider removes the BCC and then synchronized a revised version of the message.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Is re-installing the program an option?

You'd be wasting your time. Profile files are stored separately from the Thunderbird program files. The program files are static and do not change (except when you upgrade the Thunderbird application version). Because we store profile and program files separately, you can uninstall Thunderbird without losing your messages and settings, and if something goes wrong with a Thunderbird update your information will still be available. It also means that you don't have to reinstall Thunderbird in order to delete your information or troubleshoot a problem.

What is your anti-virus software?
creator: christ1

content: Thanks for your response. Webroot is the anti-virus. Is there a troubleshooting process within Thunderbird or is it just the generic Microsoft troubleshooting one (pretty useless)? What do you think might be causing these malfunctions, and what do you suggest doing to fix them?
creator: anthonyduo

content:
Anti-virus software can block or even corrupt Thunderbird mail files.

As a troubleshooting step you can try to start Windows 10 in safe mode with networking enabled.

Windows safe mode disables anti-virus software. Does the problem go away?

These are some generic suggestions to avoid problems with anti-virus software.

Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Don't let your anti-virus software scan incoming and outgoing messages.

Don't let your anti-virus software scan attachments.

Don't let your anti-virus software intercept your secure connection to the server.

Remove any add-ons your anti-virus software may have installed in Thunderbird.

Keep it working. http://kb.mozillazine.org/Keep_it_working_-_Thunderbird

And last but not least, backup your Thunderbird profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile
creator: christ1

content:
This bug was fixed in V101 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1734161 which apparently lead top https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1791854

Perhaps there is a regression from the second fix. I suggest you actually file a bug for this.

creator: mp956

content:
TB has automatically created the same folders in my mailbox on the server (of my internet service provider) and moved the messages to the same folders.

If your account is IMAP, then this is exactly what's expected. You may be better off using POP instead, but the decision which account type to use is ultimately up to you. Make yourself familiar with the differences between the two types. Google is your friend. With the assumption above, to switch from IMAP to POP, see http://kb.mozillazine.org/Convert_a_POP_account_to_a_IMAP_account

I like to work offline and cut off the internet connection.

You can switch Thunderbird to offline mode - see https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1022683 Note, with POP, there is only a local Draft folder.

Before starting to mess with it, make sure to create a full backup of your Thunderbird profile. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile
creator: christ1

content: Thunderbird supports CalDAV natively, the Provider add-on is no longer needed. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1396346

content:
dsjones54 said
Switched to a VPN last month, but no problems with that and email until today.

Comcast do not allow sending unless you are using an IP address allocated by them to their network. ipso facto a VPN always leads to failure unless the IP is a comcast one.

I suggest turn off the VPN and see if the problem goes away as I expect it will. Note you can use a google SMTP server with appropriate setup for your comcast account. Fundamentally I sort of wish folk in the USA would just stop using ISP email addresses they are just hard work to keep going because of the framework they impose.

Hello

I assume that you mean 'on this forum', because if it's about Thunderbird all mail is private by default. Yes, if you click the user's icon, you get to a user page where there is a button 'Private message'.
creator: gp1234

content: gp, Thanks for your reply. If the person whose icon I click doesn't want private messages, do I get a notifcation of that? SweetTasha.
creator: sweettasha

content: I have taken a look at the settings for my account and I don't see a way to disable private messages. If someone don't answer to a private message, either voluntarily or by mistake, I don't think there is any notification.
creator: gp1234

content:
You can select a particular person by clicking on the username or avatar and opening in a new tab to see a 'Private Message' option OR access it via your own Profile Inbox.

Sending a message means message is sent and you have a copy in the Sent folder of Profile. There will be no notification of any type unless the recipient chooses to send one.

Private messageing is normally used for eg: thank someone for their help OR to ask someone if they could look at a specific question and provide link to question or maybe chat on a topic that is not necessarilly Thunderbird related. It's often used by people who offer help on Thunderbird to converse with other people who help on Thunderbird.

It should not be used to ask Thunderbird questions which should be asked in the forum. The reason all questions and responses are posted in forum questions is so that many people may benefit from the content. It also means several people can offer assitance in one discussion. It's a community forum created and used to benefit the community. People who freely help on the forum are unpaid volunteers, but their time is valuable. It would be considered impolite to presume personal unpaid assistance by circumnavigating an open discussion.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Todd-Hall, You mention that thanking a volunteer for posting their question is one reason to send a private message, I believe that a similar reason is to discuss with the volunteer something that casts a negative light on the author of a question (me in this particular case). That type of discussion should not be public. If I'm unable to convince the volunteer of my objection, that's the end of it. The forum isn't meant to be a place to discuss the merits. In that case I might want to (privately) get the opinion of a moderator. Is there a list of moderators available to the forum users?

content:
Fundamentally there is little to no demand. The demand is for "pretty" and "modern" and generally without an complexity. Hide the menu, reduce feature clutter make the user interface respond to gorilla sized thumbs. Everyone uses touch. Or perhaps not, I like my mouse and keyboard and my cluttered information dense interface.

Historically there have been a number of addons that have generated Eudora type statistics as to frequency of contact etc. But take up was minimal at best. This is the one I used in the day https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/mail-summaries/?src=search until it was no longer compatible due to interface changes.

Now it appears choices are largely reduced to in V102 through authors not updating their addons to https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/thirdstats/?src=search
creator: MattAuSupport
